53:30 So now I'm a bit confused because there are THREE ways to think about multiplying matrices. You've talked about multiplying whole columns (hadn't quite gotten used to that) and now the ADINA way. ok, moving on…thanks for another great lesson.
w2 is the force from spring 2 on mass 1. It is downward, so it is along gravity, not opposite gravity. Hope that helped!

I hope this is not too late. A spring is modelled as exerting inward force of w at both ends. The force is of same magnitude at either end. --->...center of spring...<-----. With this convention everything works out.

For anyone wondering the same, I found his interpretation to be a bit non-intuitive, the simpler way is just to draw a free body diagram of the masses, with two spring forces, one up and one down and one gravity force pointing down.
